turn.text: Wait a minute.
Would it need it or do you want something else?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: No, I want something else besides that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What else do you want?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: I think they're going to give the hearing before they take the license.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I understood you to say that by custom at least, if one knew about the opportunity, the Registrar would allow him to appeal until the State decided the case.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes, but why should he lose his license first Your Honor?
That's the issue in the case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, that he loses license before the Registrar acts?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's right.
That's the bottom line issue in this case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He lose --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I thought the Registrar was the one who deprived him of his license.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: He does but -- and I'm saying that he should have a hearing before the Registrar takes that action.
What he -- what the Registrar should does that he does in hundreds of other cases, Your Honor, pursuant to statutory scheme in Massachusetts --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think you should really move until the question is asked.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Because his question was, could the Registrar relieve him of his license immediately?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: He does in fact take his license immediately.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When he refused to take the test, the Registrar takes it?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's correct.
As soon as he gets the letter from the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How in the world can he do that?
He is in an entirely different city, isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: He sends a notice as soon as he gets the notice from --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, what I mean he can't do it unless he gets the notice, can he?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That was the question.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Well, I'm sorry I didn't understand it that way Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you should wait and then get into it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The Registrar gets the notice.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then he's in the position to act unless the individual tried, appears and gives him reasons why that shouldn't be done.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: I know by statute, he is required to act, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I thought you said that custom accorded the individual a right to be heard before the Registrar.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: After the revocation, after the notice goes out then he by custom he can get an immediate hearing but --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Still Mr. Hagopian, I don't think you made it clear.
There's a time interval between the revocation which can be done by mail and the turning in of the physical piece of paper which may be a few days later, that's the later date he gets the hearing.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's right and he can't drive in the meantime either Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's the heart of your case, and you're not making it at all clear.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes the -- he cannot drive, the minute he gets the notice, he has to cease and desist.
He then physically has to get that notice to the Registrar.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And you also, are you not contending that before he gets the notice he has absolutely no right to appear before the magistrate or whatever is called?
That's right.
That's your point?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, has absolutely no right.
And if, even he does which is what happened to Montrym's case through his attorney, the Registrar didn't pay any attention to him because the Registrar has no discretion under the statute.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I understand you to alledge traffic violation.
You can't immediately go before the magistrate?
Immediately?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: I'm not sure I understand that question.
You mean before the Registrar --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When you are arrested for violation of traffic code --

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- of Massachusetts.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Can't you go directly before magistrate, then and there if one is available?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: You mean to trial, Your Honor on the criminal charges?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you say how to do to it, you said you can't even go to it?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: You can't go to the Registrar.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I said the magistrate.
You can't go to the magistrate, can you?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: We can go to a lower court and criminal court, that's correct Your Honor.
But the issue of whether he takes the Breathalyzer will not usually come up in that proceedings -- in the criminal proceedings.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Are you sure of that?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How are you sure?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Because it's inadmissible as grants for mistrial for fact that the police introduced the fact that he refused --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Even if the magistrate says, I don't think this man is drunk and turns him loose.
He can do that.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He can do that.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought so.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: But the Registrar will still revoke his license.
Even if he's found not guilty --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm not talking about --

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes, I understand that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- while if you say he could do.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Well, let me say in general Your Honor, the criminal proceedings do not come before the registry action.
This is an unusual case in that sense.
Usually, the criminal proceedings come after the registry revokes so this is a rare case to have a criminal proceeding before the Registrar takes his action.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Hagopian, let me ask the question.
Would you challenge the constitutionality of the statute if it worked in this way?

If the police sent a notice and simultaneously send it to the person arrested and also to the Registrar which said in substance in such and such a date, your license will be revoked, you may appear at that time to object if you with to it, if you don't you'd be automatically revoked.
Would you have any objection to that statute?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: No, in fact that's a procedure that you can --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: All you're really talking about is the suspension that the fact that there's an automatic suspension for the interval of time between the notice to the magistrate and the time he can go in and demand hearing.
Do you say that would be alright if it was a notice of what they're proposed to do rather than the facts that was accorded?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's correct and that procedure is inexistence in Massachusetts by the registry in several other statutes.
And I pointed that out in my brief.
He sends a 14-day notice and he says I intend to revoke your license in 14 days and if you object to it, you can come in and have a hearing before the 14 days.
And that procedure is used in thousands of cases.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, he should be -- give the ground upon which he proposed to do it.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Oh!
Yes, yes he does.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in this case would be because of your refusal to take a Breathalyzer case in such and such a date.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And I thought also the hearing that you would require would be more than what custom here would afford.
You would want to be able to call any kind of witness you wanted?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: I don't take that position, Your Honor.
I just think that that I don't even take the position he has to have a hearing before the registry.
He's got an opportunity to respond in some way, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let me ask you.
Suppose you have all the hearings that you wanted before the suspension, do you suppose that?
And the Registrar says now you got all the hearing you want and you say yes to all the hearing, I now find there is probable cause to suspend your license.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if you want a full hearing some other time, we'll give it to you.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That would satisfy you?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: It certainly would.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you don't think, you don't think then just a police report furnishes probable cause to suspend the license even for a day?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
I think that's really the heart of the issue to due process clause.
There must be some interaction with the citizen himself.
You've got the dignicy interest and the representative interest.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, when you say --

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: It must be covered by the due process clause and that's totally absent.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When you say the opportunity to respond, you say you don't want an evidentiary hearing but you want an opportunity to respond.
What would the opportunity to respond consist of?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Well, I don't think that this Court have resolved that issue.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Or you're the one that --

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Well, I certainly think he has an opportunity.
He should have the opportunity to file an affidavit to respond with charges in writing.
That's an absolute minimum.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: i.e.and what would be the issue be, that he did refuse?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Right.
Exactly and if he files an affidavit --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Just a minute, would that be the only issue?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: No, because there's three other issues under the statutes before the registry can revoke.
He must show that there was probable cause for the initial arrest.
He must show that there was a valid arrest.
And that involves whether he was on a public way and multitude of other factors.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There would be three issues.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.
Three issues that Massachusetts sets out as a basis for the revocation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And those would be the only issue.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And then what if the Registrar after a hearing that he had contested all three of those by an affidavit saying the police were wrong and all three said, fine you can have your opportunity to respond, and your license is suspended.
No, no problem?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You'd say no problem if there was probable cause for that, is that your position?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but the whole (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: They've got -- they've got to find that this is at least the prima facie evidence that the government has met there burden improving the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's a little more than probable cause?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Well, I suppose it is Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, of course it is, most probable cause of termination to ex parte?

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.
Well, no.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: In criminal proceedings Your Honor that may be true.
In a criminal proceeding, that issue of the search warrant is distinguished in Fuentes versus Shevin and that's a criminal proceedings.
And I also believe it was distinguish more recently in a case last term which I think you took the majority opinion on and --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I'm just suggesting to you that there are an awful lot of important probable cause if terminations that involved loss of liberty that are made ex parte and made only by one person in writing.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: In a criminal sense, yes.
In a civil sense, I know of no thing --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Are you saying this Court --

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: -- that the Court has ever held were an ex parte that could be a deprivation of a property interest in the civil sense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You can deprive a person of liberty --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But not property?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- but not property ex parte?
That's a -- that's a client argument.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Not in -- in a criminal sense, yes.
In a civil sense, no.

I know of no case that this Court has held other if there is an emergency doctrine where there could be an ex parte and that's the issue, an ex parte deprivation of property or liberty in the civil sense.

Leaving the criminal side if the law reside; in the civil sense, I know of no case this Court has ever held absolute emergency condition that there could be an ex parte deprivation.Even on an affidavit, I know of no case that this Court has ever held to that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I am hunting around, a little I'm sure I could find --

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Well, I know that there are number of old cases.
I just like to say one last thing, Your Honor.

The State has absolutely no interest in taking this immediately taking this drunks off of the road, Your Honor under the procedure in Massachusetts now everybody whose drunk 95% are now going a rehabilitative program after they convicted they are still on the road.
Why is it?

What justification is there for the state to take away that man's right to some hearing before the state takes -- the registry takes any action if in fact, after even if they are drunk and are all convicted they are all on the road anyway, Your Honor.
There is no legitimate state --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They are not for 90 days if they refuse to take the Breathalyzer test under the present act.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: That's -- that's correct Your Honor.
But that's not the issue.
The issue is, is there any immediate reason to take to impose that 90-day sanction.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, the Massachusetts by enacting this legislation said there yes, there is.
Or else it would not have acted the legislation.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Well, I submit to you, Your Honor that they have enacted it because they feel that instant punishment.
The metering out of instant punishment --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Suspension of license --

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: -- is a deterrent for people who refuse to take the Breathalyzer.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Precisely, because they thought there was a need for it.
Presumably, they would have enacted the law.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That's what Judge Campbell said, wasn't it that purpose was to deter people from refusing to take the Breathalyzer.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And I think that's important to our system of justice.
And it always has been.
I've never known why don't we do away with trials and we can insist, say we'll put you in jail before we give you a trial and you can stay in there and then you can have your trial.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Maybe you should.

turn.speaker: robert_w_hagopian
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Hagopian
turn.text: I don't think that deters crime.
I don't think that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Maybe we should do away with oral argument.
Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
